Posts.Content: BettyBoob, For your health's sake, I would google IBC (inflammatory breast cancer). That is what I have. You have several of the signs and symptoms of IBC; and if I were you, I would insist that your doctor rule out IBC by performing a biopsy.  Inflammatory breast cancer is highly aggressive, rare and usually does not show up on a routine mammogram (mine didn't).  Also, no doctor ever told me that you don't have to have a lump to have breast cancer, but it's true.  IBC usually has no lump. Please check out the signs and symptoms of IBC at ibcsupport.org and eraseibc.com.  A misdiagnosis can mean Stage IV rather than the "normal" IBC Stage IIIB.  You may not have IBC, but better safe than sorry.  My regular doctor wasn't even aware of IBC and most of the medical personnel I've seen over the last 18 months know very little about it.  Even the oncologist I went to said he would not have suspected IBC just looking at my breast.  I'm so glad that I screamed and hollered until I got the tests I need to either rule out IBC or confirm it as IBC (which it was) and got my treatment started.  With IBC you have chemo, then surgery, radiation and maybe more chemo.  If you have any questions, just ask. Claudia in Florida
Posts.Title: Worried Misfiagnosis!

Posts.Content: Excellent advice, Bonnie.  Everyone does react differently, and it really helps to have a positive attitude and laugh a lot.  I hand out a "laugh of the day" award to whoever makes me laugh the hardest when I read my email.  Believe me, I do a lot of laughing. You sure can't just sit around crying all the time.  It's much more fun to laugh. Claudia
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo not sure

Posts.Content: Many of the women in my IBC (inflammatory breast cancer) support group are stage 4. After having chemo, many have had mastectomies, more chemo at times, and radiation. Some are even NED (no evidence of disease) after all treatment was finished. When there is a positive response to the chemo, many of the doctors will advise surgery.
Posts.Title: what to do

Posts.Content: There's so much more hope for Stage 4 folks now. If your doctor says you've had a positive response to chemo and are ready for surgery, I'd say get a second opinion (if you're able to) and then go for it.
Posts.Title: what to do

Posts.Content: On 12/29/2008 Concernedrelative wrote: My Mother's physician has prescribed tamoxophin as part of her treatment for breast cancer. She has recently been experiencing bouts of diarrea almost on a daily basis. The diarrea occurs after breakfast while she is doing grocery shopping or errands. Is this typical or expected? What can be done to alleviate her distressing condition? I'm also concerned with having bouts of diarrhea.  Although I'm not taking tamoxifen, I am taking arimidex, and that is one of its side effects.  It's distressing, to say the least, and I never know when it'll hit me. Claudia
Posts.Title: side effects of tamoxophin

Posts.Content: Thanks for that info, Kim.  I wasn't aware of the link with endometrial or uterine cancer.  I don't take tamoxifen, but do take arimidex.   Claudia
Posts.Title: side effects of tamoxophin

Posts.Content: My friend uses Dr.  Bradford Carter and highly recommends him.
Posts.Title: anyone familier with Moffitt Cancer Center breast cancer program

Posts.Content: On Jan 17, 2010 5:40 PM FL33498 wrote: Does anyone know who is the best doctor in Moffitt Cancer Center breast cancer program. South Florida patient, Breast cancer, er positive, finished surgery and cheom, taking Tamoxifen, but petscan show a 1.3 cm pulmonary nodule, suspicious for tumor Need Help finding the  best doctor! I'm also in South Florida, but on east coast, and I am not familiar with the doctors at Moffitt.  I have a friend up in that general area who goes to Moffitt, and I will contact her and find out who her doctor is.  She has said he's good. Claudia
Posts.Title: anyone familier with Moffitt Cancer Center breast cancer program

Posts.Content: On Mar 03, 2012 8:13 PM CarolinaK wrote: My Primary Doc found lump a year ago, had Mammo/US/MRI nothing found. I am 36 with family history of breast cancer. I was told I simply have dense breasts and don't worry. Fast forward one year, started having breast pain in Dec. Waited two months, made appt wit doc, had another mammo, US and nothing once again. Four weeks ago, started having armpit pain and arm pain on same side as lump/breast pain. Went back to primary doc and was told I had a swollen lymph node and was referred to surgeon. Had appt. with surgeon, she said all diagnostic tests showed nothing, lymph node no longer swollen and the lump feels like just dense breast tissue. Said she could not explain armpit and arm pain. Recommended I take a gamma linolenci acid for 4 weeks and if pain persists to return and have possile MRI on shoulder to find out about armpit/arm pain. Surgeon said she would biopsy lump if I wanted but did not recommend a biopsy at this point. Has anyone here that has been diagnosed had these symptoms? Should I wait or go ahead and have the biopsy? One of the symptoms of Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC) is pain in the breast or armpit. Another sign is swollen lymph nodes in the armpit or above the collarbone. Since IBC is the most aggressive form of breast cancer, we (I am a 4-year survivor of IBC) always say, "If in doubt, rule it out", meaning rule out IBC first.  You can read about the signs and symptoms of IBC at www.eraseibc.com . It's always good to have a breast surgeon who is familiar with IBC. There are many doctors (like yours) who are not. The most definitive method is having biopsies on the breast. Most of the time there is no lump; therefore, the IBC won't show on a routine mammo, ultrasound or MRI. Do your research and get to one of the IBC clinics around the U.S. They are in at least 6 different states (TX, PA, NC, MA, MI and AZ are ones I can think of). With IBC you have chemo first, then surgery and rads, and maybe even more chemo after surgery or after rads.
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: On 2/13/2009 newmom2008 wrote: I was diagnosed with Triple Negative Metaplastic Carcinoma on 2/9/09.  2 months after I stopped breast feeding.  4.5 cm tumor on my right breast.  PET/CT finds that the cancer has spread to Lymph Notes. My medical oncology doctors are very concerned about the possibility of the cancer already spread to the entire body even though the PET/CT scan does not show.  So they are recommending Chemo (Neoadjuvent) first followed by Mastectomy. Has anyone tried neoadjuvent treatment before the surgery?  Any success stories?  I can't seem to find any testomonials. Thanks, Newmom2008 Yes, I had neoadjuvent treatment (chemo before surgery) with my IBC (inflammatory breast cancer).  It is standard treatment with aggressive cancers.  It should help to reduce the size of the tumor before surgery. Way more success in the case of IBC.  I'm really glad that I did get chemo prior to surgery, as the tumor was greatly reduced in size prior to my mastectomy.  Go for it!
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Metaplastic Carcinoma and Neoajuvant

Posts.Content: Everyone reacts differently to chemo and, of course, a lot depends upon what chemo combination you're receiving also.  I had Adriamycin and Cytoxin and had no side effects and no problems while receiving same.  It was the same when they gave me Taxotere.  Others have many side effects.  I consider myself very lucky to have had none.  Ask your oncologist what side effects you may experience, but don't expect to experience all. Hopefully, you'll not have any side effects.   Good luck with your treatment.
Posts.Title: chemo

Posts.Content: On 4/24/2009 carolyn97222 wrote: classid="clsid:38481807-CA0E-42D2-BF39-B33AF135CC4D" id=ieooui> Demand an MRI - see my story below: NORMAL mammogram - URGENT - READ THIS DX April 2008, 60 yrs., Right Breast - 2 Infiltrating Ductal Carcinoma tumors, diameters 9.5 & 3.5 mm, Nuclear grade 3, ER & PR +, HER negative, Lymph vascular involvement Node positive (8/21), Right Modified Radical Mastectomy (MRM) April 2008   I am 61 years old and have had at least 30+ normal mammograms. In fact in Jan., I had a "normal" mammogram and ultrasound. BUT, I knew something was wrong because I had dimpling and an inverted nipple in one breast. I had pain in both breasts, and I had heard that breast cancer was not painful so I wasn't worried. Boy, was I wrong! Because of the dimpling and inverted nipple, they did an MRI.  I was shocked to find out that the one breast had a 4" and a 1.5" tumor - basically, my whole breast was full of the two tumors. It was estimated that I had the large tumor for 15-20 years. Later I was told that I had dense, fibrous breasts and that's why all of the mammograms were normal. Recently, I told my 40-yr old daughter to demand an MRI after her normal mammogram and ultrasound. It was discovered that she had a 1/2" tumor! So, if you know of anyone that has been told they have dense, fibrous breast tissue, tell them to demand an MRI in order to get a much more accurate exam of their breasts. This could save thousands of lives a year! Carolyn Carolyn, You mentioned " pain, dimpling and an inverted nipple".  Were you ever told that you had Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC) or were you told you had something else?  Those are some of the main symptoms of IBC, which I have, and I just wondered since you didn't mentioned IBC in your posting. Since IBC doesn't usually present itself with a lump and doesn't usually show up on a routine mammogram (you need a diagnostic mammogram which specifically looks for the nesting or sheeting of IBC), many times women are misdiagnosed. A biopsy is done to rule out IBC or to confirm the diagnosis. IBC is highly aggressive, can appear seemingly overnight, and is treated first with chemo, then surgery, and followed by radiation and maybe more chemo.  Women are always told to feel for lumps and get their annual mammos. They should also be told that there's a breast cancer that doesn't usually have a lump and that doesn't show on a routine mammo...that's IBC. If doctors would tell their patients to look for ANY changes in their breasts and to notify their doctors of those changes, it might save more lives. We also need to help educate the medical profession and the general public about the signs and symptoms of IBC and the importance of early detection and treatment.  That's been my mission since my diagnosis in August 2007.  To learn about the signs and symptoms of IBC, go to eraseibc.com and get information that can save lives. Claudia in South FL
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: On 1/17/2009 Rainyid wrote: Hi Claudia,   Thank you for your response and the information....  I did go to the doctor and they believe that I have an infection in a cyst in that breast.... They drained the cyst and sent it in for cytology and other testing.... He put me on a strong antobioc... I knew that I had the cyst and we had decided to just leave it alone.... I had it drained one other time but it never acted the way that my breast is doing now.... With the IBC do the symptoms come and go???  My redness is almost gone and the fever is not as warm....  With all of that fluid removed my back is not hurting....  This really has me concerned and I appreciate all of the info that you can offer....  Thank You So Much ~~~~ Rainy22   Rainy, Hopefully all you have is an infection of some kind and not IBC.  As far as I know, the symptoms of IBC do not come and go.  My symptoms did not go away until I was treated with chemo.  I'll keep you in my prayers.  Do stay in touch and let us know your diagnosis. Claudia
Posts.Title: Red and Sore Breast/ I had breast cancer two and one half years ago

Posts.Content: On 1/15/2009 Rainyid wrote: I had breast cancer two and one half years ago.... It was followed up with radiation.... All of a sudden my breast has turned a bright red and is very warm.... It is just like it has been sunburned....  It is just as red as when I was taking the radiation treatments....  Has anyone else had this problem this far down the road after having cancer??? I go to my doctor in the morning and I am hoping for good news... The symptoms you describe are signs of IBC (inflammatory breast cancer).  Please do some research because if it is IBC, you need to get your diagnosis ASAP and start treatment.  Treatment starts with chemo, then surgery, followed by radiation and maybe more chemo.  Do not delay in getting a diagnosis as IBC is a highly aggressive breast cancer.  You can read all about IBC at www.eraseibc.com.  I hope you don't have IBC; but if you do, I hope you will seek immediate treatment. Claudia
Posts.Title: Red and Sore Breast/ I had breast cancer two and one half years ago

Posts.Content: I have IBC (inflammatory breast cancer) which usually does NOT present itself with a lump. Some of the signs and symptoms of IBC are: * Rapid, unusual increase in breast size * Redness, rash, blotchiness on breast (only symptom I had) * Persistent itching of breast or nipple * Lump or thickening of breast tissue * Stabbing pain and/or soreness of breast * Feverish breast * Swelling of lymph nodes under the arm or above the collar bone * Dimpling or ridging of breast * Flattening or retracting of nipple * Nipple discharge or change in pigmented area around the nipple The above symptoms or signs may also indicate a benign breast disorder. However, ANY change to your breast should be reported to your physician immediately.
Posts.Title: Symptoms of Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: On 7/26/2007 Rett1954 wrote:   On 7/16/2007 Leemg wrote: Thanks Rett!  You sound like a true soldier for the Lord.  My sister is actually a pastor but I have had difficulty at times with my relationship with the Lord.  Thought I was able to see and be a part of some of His workings in the past but had a situation which cast some confusion and doubt, maybe it was just in my interpretation.  I know He is there but for some reason I haven't been able to reach out as I should and it is not just because of the cancers.  People in my life have been disappointing and this has hurt maybe like l hurt Him by not being there.  Maybe that is what He wants me to feel and understand.  I'm sure I'll have plenty of time to ponder while recuperating from thryoid cancer surgery and preparing for treatment as I've learned it is a arduous process.  Have a blessed day! Well my dear when I was first diagnoised I asked God to help me be a good representative and not just look downtrodden and worn. But I have come to find that God is not like us ...Thank God LoL we really are freely given love and grace and mercy. I just love the way he made provision for us before we were even born...he God just wants to spend time with you and me daily, like any good father he cares and this is one of my statements that has kept me ...he does not love me any more than he loves you , he loves us all the same the best he can.  So my dear no condemnation...the enemy cannot rob you ...so every day I have this note I taped to my bathroom wall right above the tissue...Today I know that God is giving me his best and I rest in knowing that his will is being worked out for me.  So no matter the test or task or surgery we are going to just use the words of the Bible over your life...do not add to them and do not take from them and do not limit God by saying maybe he  is teaching us a lesson. So declare the word over your life and I agree with you that no weapon formed against you will prosper....and that you will not experience all the negative side affects. Be blessed, had my breast MRI done this past Monday and my husband went with me and fell in the hospital due to water on the floor ...what a test ...he had to be seen in emergency but is back at work yesterday. Life is never dull... Rett          Rett, Like you, I live in Broward County.  I have recently been diagnosed with IBC, inflammatory breast cancer.  Please check out ibcsupport.org and find out how important it is to IMMEDIATELY get a biopsy and a diagnosis if you do have IBC.  I hope and pray you don't.  However, the ibc support group is a wonderful bunch of people that I've come to love in a very short time.  They are so willing to help in so many ways. God bless you, my friend. Claudia
Posts.Title: Can someone please give me some peace

Posts.Content: On 9/11/2007 Rett1954 wrote: Claudia, Thank you, so much for the information right now believe it or not this is what I am dealing with.  almost hate to answer but of course my last chemo treatment was on the 30th and I was taking off on the 31st making it a long birthday weekend...well Claudia and you know it is going to be something when I start like this...well of course my doctor could not place the needle in the correct place and I left with swelling and bleeding and I had to change  the bandage and that never happens....so by about 3am Fri the 31 I was woke and I had so much pain that I just could not stand it...called both the oncologist and the surgeon Well both did call back and the oncologist called back quickly I explained the pain  that I was in and did I need to go to emergency ? he said no he would call in a perscription on my behalf and he did but my surgeon asked that I come in and he gave me 2 prescriptions ..well at the end of the day I was taking  the pain pills left and right and of course this was the holiday weekend...so my next appointment was on Tuesday at 2:30...when I went he worked me into the  schedule the next day to have the port removed...so I was out all last week spent the birthday and last week taking pills and still taking them....so I am  so black and blue and still barely able to sleep just tired and I was a little scaredon what was happening that I took pictures of the bruising and I of course contacted my primary to get a second opinion referral.... So right now the right breast seems ok but I am now dealing with my left breast and removal of my port..... Thank you for your love and concern Rett   Rett, So far, I've only had my first chemo treatment (last Friday), and so far no problems at all.  I haven't had a port put in yet.  I have heard and read so much for it and so much against it.  Will wait for results of my bone scan (which I'm still waiting to have done) before I decide if I will have one put in or not.  My veins are small, roll a lot, and are hard to find. So, if I need more than the 4 chemo treatments prior to surgery, I may have one put in.  My thoughts and prayers are with you.  I'm so sorry that you had such a hard time with your last treatment. It's pretty scary at times, isn't it? Hugs, Claudia
Posts.Title: Can someone please give me some peace

Posts.Title: Can someone please give me some peace

Posts.Content: When you say "breaking out", explain what it looks like. Tell us if she has any other symptoms. What kind of tests has she had and if she has seen a breast specialist. I had a slight pink/red blotchiness on one breast and no other symptoms and still ended up with a diagnosis of Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC). Tell her to check the signs and symptoms of IBC at www.eraseIBC.com and read all about it. There are many things it could be, but she might want to "rule out IBC" since it's highly aggressive.
Posts.Title: BREAKING OUT ON BREAST AND PAIN

Posts.Content: I'm in total agreement with Tre.  She does give good advice here.
Posts.Title: Help Please question on Quality of Medical Advice

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with IBC in August 2007. Please listen to the people here who are telling you to get the correct kind of biopsy/biopsies (not lumpectomy) to get a correct diagnosis. If you do have IBC, be sure you get doctors who are familiar with IBC who know that you treat it with chemo first, then surgery, then either more chemo or radiation. You DO NOT have surgery before any chemo. You can also check out The Inflammatory Breast Cancer Foundation (www.eraseibc.com) for signs, symptoms and treatment. The best support group online is at www.ibcsupport.org . The women there have "been there, done that" and are quite knowledgeable.
Posts.Title: Inflammatory breast cancer

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with IBC in August 2007. Please listen to the people here who are telling you to get the correct kind of biopsy/biopsies (not lumpectomy) to get a correct diagnosis. If you do have IBC, be sure you get doctors who are familiar with IBC who know that you treat it with chemo first, then surgery, then either more chemo or radiation. You DO NOT have surgery before any chemo. You can also check out The Inflammatory Breast Cancer Foundation (www.eraseibc.com) for signs, symptoms and treatment. The best support group online is at www.ibcsupport.org . The women there have "been there, done that" and are quite knowledgeable.
Posts.Title: Inflammatory breast cancer

Posts.Content: Bonnie, I had Adriamycin and Cytoxin (4 x every three weeks), then Taxotere (4 x every three weeks).  I had no problems with either, although other people did.  In fact, my husband and I would go out to eat right after I finished my treatments.  Keep a positive attitude...that does help.  Claudia in FL
Posts.Title: Terrified of Chemo - HELP!

Posts.Content: Bonnie, I was 65 when diagnosed and when I started chemo.  I think you can do whatever you're up to doing while on chemo.  No one told me I couldn't go out to eat or be around people.  I did try to stay away from any people who were sick; but other than that, I pretty well did as I pleased.  If I felt like going out to eat, we did.  It sure beat cooking...LOL.  Claudia
Posts.Title: Terrified of Chemo - HELP!

Posts.Content: You're very welcome, Tracy.  Glad I was of help to you.
Posts.Title: Anyone else have this

Posts.Content: You did the right thing by having it checked out.  However, one thing you must know is that YOU DON'T HAVE TO HAVE A LUMP TO HAVE BREAST CANCER.  I have IBC (inflammatory breast cancer) and it normally doesn't present itself with a lump, nor does it usually show on a routine mammogram.  You usually need a diagnostic mammo (which is specifically looking for the sheeting or nesting of IBC tumors) or other type of testing (ultrasound, CT or PET scan, etc.).   I sincerely hope you have a benign condition, but I do hope you will do some research on IBC.  I wish you luck with your testing and hope you will let us know how it turns out.
Posts.Title: Anyone else have this

Posts.Content: On 4/9/2009 Nancyb wrote: need info when i had radiation in 2002 at university hospitals of cleveland they made a form of plaster or fiberglass of the position i had to lay in so i wouldn't move. my siter in law is having radiation locally and they did not make a form for her to lay in. did anyone else have a form as i did or was my radiologist being extra careful? thanks for any info , n b Nancyb,  I had tattoos on my body as well as a form that I had to lay in so I wouldn't move while I had radiation.  Maybe it depends on where the cancer is and where you have the radiation. Claudia
Posts.Title: radiation

Posts.Content: Re: . 2 greywhite lesions in the breast tissue, each ~ 2-3 cm, arranged in nests, sheets, cords. They are around 1.5 cm apart.   There was similar wording on my pathology report and my surgeon referred to my tumors as nesting or sheeting rather than lumps.  I have inflammatory breast cancer...no lump, just the nesting and sheeting of tumors.  I didn't know other types of breast cancer had nesting or sheeting. Claudia
Posts.Title: interpreting pathology report; post mastectomy

Posts.Content: Yes, we did discuss the new (and stupid) packaging for Arimidex.  As I stated then, Astra-Zeneca advised me when I called that each pharmacy could order the pills in either the blister pack or in bottles.  My pharmacy is now only ordering them in the bottles because of all the complaints they received.  When I picked up my pills this month, I had my bottle back.  Boy, it takes so little to make me happy...LOL.
Posts.Title: Arimidex Packaging

Posts.Content: In August 2007 I was diagnosed with Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC). There are women in my online support group who have been around for up to 17 years with IBC.  Protocol calls for treatment with chemotherapy, then mastectomy and then radiation and possibly more chemo.  I have finished radiation a few weeks ago and am taking Arimidex (oral pill) for 5 years. It does have some side effects (as you can see by some of the other messages), but it does help prevent recurrences.  Some of the signs and symptoms of IBC are rapid increase in breast size; redness, rash or blotchiness on the breast (this is only symptom I had), consistent pain and/or soreness of the breast; lump, or thickening or dimpling of the skin of the breast; warmth or tenderness of the breast; lymph node swelling under the arm or above the collarbone; flattening of the nipple or discharge from the nipple.  Most doctors want to treat you for mastitis with a course of antibiotics. If there is no response to the antibiotics within 5 days, you should immediately demand that IBC be ruled out since it is so highly aggressive. IBC lies in sheets or nests, not the usual lymp women are told to look for, thus rarely seen on routine mammograms.   I'll be glad to answer any other questions you may have. You might also want to check into the support group at www.ibcsupport.org.  It's a wonderful group of IBC survivors and caregivers who have the most wonderful knowledge and share it so freely. Claudia in FL
Posts.Title: imflamitory breast cancer

Posts.Content: Yes, that's happened to many of my IBC sisters. What are the signs and symptoms you're having? A biopsy won't even help if it's not done in the correct place. Hopefully, they will do more than one biopsy while they have you there. I had 3 biopsies done on my breast, and they confirmed that I had Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC). Learn the signs and symptoms at the Inflammatory Breast Cancer Foundation (www.eraseibc.com).
Posts.Title: mri did show breast cancer

Posts.Content: When I clicked on the link you furnished, I got a message saying they had redone their site and that page had been moved.
Posts.Title: Improving the efficacy of radiation therapy

Posts.Content: That is a wonderful tribute to your sister.  It brought tears to my eyes.  As the oldest of 4 sisters, I know the closeness you're talking about.  It just wouldn't be the same without any one of us not around. Claudia in South FL
Posts.Title: My wonderful sister

Posts.Content: Paddy, Check at the top right-hand corner of this page and click on "Message Center".  That's where the private messges are stored.  I just discovered that myself and saw my message to you of Apr 30 in response to your message to me. Claudia
Posts.Title: My wonderful sister

Posts.Content: That's a new one for me. The kind of breast cancer I got was Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC) in 2007...no lump and much harder to diagnose. I'd really be interested to hear what this turns out to be. Do keep in touch on the board. Good luck to you, too.
Posts.Title: Question about symptom

Posts.Content: Your post gets right to the heart of the situation...education.  When I was diagnosed with IBC in August 2007, my primary care physician wanted to set me up for surgery ASAP.  I had to inform her that my research online (thank you, ibcresearch.org) said that chemo was the first treatment.  If I can do research and learn what "might be ailing me", why can't a doctor? I knew after reading and researching that I had either mastitis or IBC.  At age 65, I was pretty sure it was  probably IBC and not mastitis.  Yet, I was forced to go through two different 10-day antibiotic treatments since the doctor was pretty sure it was probably mastitis.  I finally got a diagnostic mammo, specifically looking for the "sheeting or nesting" of the tumors in IBC, and the report suggested I get a biopsy to rule out IBC.  In my case, it was to rule it in.  The surgeon did 4 separate biopsies on my breast and they confirmed the diagnosis of IBC. By early September, I was getting my first chemo treatment.  My last chemo was in March of 2008, followed by a right MRM in April and almost 7 weeks of daily radiation in June/July.  Every day now I take this tiny little white pill called Arimidex to hopefully keep the cancer from recurring.  Wicked side effects...oh yes; but if it works, I'll take it for a full 5 years.  It's now been almost a year since I saw my oncologist, and I will see him for my follow-up in August.  I have no idea if he'll order any tests or if I have to have a specific complaint to get any testing done.  My heartfelt thanks to all the wonderful people I've met through my association with ibcresearch.org.  They are the ones who educated me and now it's my mission to educate everyone I come in contact with every day, including the medical profession...especially the medical profession, I should say.  No one should be misdiagnosed or have their diagnosis delayed because their doctor isn't aware of the signs and symptoms of IBC.  Note:  I only had one symptom and was even told I didn't have enough of the symptoms to have IBC.  Yeah, right. Gotta educate these doctors and also make everyone aware of the signs and symptoms of IBC (Inflammatory Breast Cancer).
Posts.Title: "Rare breast cancer is deadly"......Dr. Gott

Posts.Content: Bonnie, One thing you need to remember is that everyone reacts differently to the various chemos.  I had no side effects with my A/C treatments or with my Taxotere treatments. I do consider myself lucky.  My hubby and I would go out to breakfast or lunch after I finished my treatments.  The only thing I can remember botherine me was the fact that I would want to take a nap some afternoons. I had chemo from Sept 2007 through Feb 2008. I had a right mastectomy this April, then had almost 7 weeks of radiation therapy. I only had some minor burning in the area above my collarbone. We had late afternoon or early evening appointments for radiation, so we usually went out to eat supper after my treatments.  Again, I consider myself lucky. The main problems I've had are from the Arimidex pill which I've been taking since March 2008.  I believe I've had every side effect I've ever seen listed by anyone at one time or another.  However, in spite of the joint pain, sleeplessness, nausea, vomiting and other side effects from time to time, as long as it works I will continue taking it. Good luck with your treatment.  Keep laughing and thinking positive thoughts.  Claudia
Posts.Title: Mammo,Sono,Breast MRI - neg Positive Nodes

Posts.Content: Noel and Sue, As someone with IBC (Inflammatory Breast Cancer), I do hope and pray that Noel just has an infection.  Since I was diagnosed in August 2007, I have made it my mission in life to educate the public AND the medical profession about the signs and symptoms of IBC.  Almost everyone I've dealt with or talked to in the medical profession have no idea about any of the signs and symptoms of IBC.  I carry IBC brochures with me at all times and pass them out whereever I go.  It absolutely amazes me that doctors will continue to say "nothing is wrong" or "you only have an infection" when you actually have the most highly aggressive form of breast cancer you can get.  I was told that I wasn't red enough and that I only had one symptom and had to have ALL of them to have IBC.  If I can do research online, I think doctors should be able to do the same. I don't think that's a lot to ask. And, of course, sometimes the doctor might want to do certain tests, and the insurance company says "no" (but that's another story).  My prayers are with you, Noel.  Let us know how you're doing and what you learn.  Claudia in South FL
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer signs and symptoms

Posts.Content: Have you learned anything yet? Your symptoms sound like a few of the symptoms of Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC), which is what I was diagosed with in 2007. Please check out the signs and symptoms at www.eraseibc.com . You may want to print out information from the website and take it to your doctor. Where are you located? If you do have IBC, there are several IBC specific cancer centers around the US. Don't be scared. There's plenty of support for you.
Posts.Title: Breast is swollen and very tender

Posts.Content: On 1/28/2009 alt08 wrote: Okay, I don't know if anyone can help me or not but if someone could that would be awesome.  My right breast, which used to be my larger breast and now is smaller, started out with some wierd itching/stabbing pain inside the breast toward my sternum, took antibiotics, took antifungal, itching still there.  Now my nipple itches like crazy and is really painful it ius also slightly a different color than my left nipple.  On monday i found a ridge type mas right along my breast bone in my breast and the tissue there is thicker, this morning i found a pea sized lump right in the same area.  I have an ultra sound on wednesday but can get the results until the 18th.  Oh and the skin on the underside of my breast went numb this morning.  I was wondering if anyone ever had symptoms like those and if so what happened? Please check out the signs and symptoms of IBC (Inflammatory Breast Cancer) at www.eraseibc.com.  You have described several of the signs and symptoms of IBC, which is very aggressive.  I have IBC, and it is nothing to fool around with, is commonly misdiagnosed, and many doctors have never seen a case of IBC.  Feel free to contact me if you have any further questions.
Posts.Title: Symptoms

Posts.Content: On 7/26/2009 Sewwonderfulwoman wrote:   On 7/20/2009 Kygrandma wrote: I was diagnosed last year with breast cancer and underwent radiation. I was then placed on Arimidex. I encountered numerous problems with stiffness of joints, agressive arthritis, and tons of muscular pain. Recently(thru a change of doctors) I was placed on Aromasin.  I am beginning to have more joint stiffness but am still trying this med.  There is a very noticable difference in my hair.  It is really thinning out.  Anyone with any suggestions?  Or has this impacted any one else???  I sure don't want to feel like LoneRanger. I'm on Arimidex (2+ yrs) and right after I was placed on it my hair started falling out and became much much thinner, particularly at the back of the crown and the front of the head. My solution to the hair problem was a human hair wig that clips to my hair.  No more bad hair days and thicker bangs than I'd ever had!  What I'd love to know from those who had this same problem is:  does the hair come in better once they quit the aromatase inhibitors? I'd like to know if the Arimidex I've been on for about 16 months is what is causing my hair to thin out.  It had come back in nice and thick after my chemo treatments, just like it was prior to cancer.  Now I notice that it's thinning out mainly in the front.  Hadn't given a thought to Arimidex maybe causing it.  I have enough side effects from it...gimme a break.
Posts.Title: Hair Thinning Problems

Posts.Content: On 8/10/2009 Kygrandma wrote: Yes, these drugs are all in the same family.  They all can cause hair loss.  My wig looks nice.   It's way too hot in South Florida to wear a wig all the time.  Maybe I can find some of the spray to cover my scalp where it shows through.  It's only in a few places anyway.  Most places are still quite thick...thank goodness.
Posts.Title: Hair Thinning Problems

Posts.Content: Kailee, I do not want to alarm you, but I do believe you have several signs of IBC (Inflammatory Breast Cancer), which is what I was diagnosed with in 2007. Please check out the signs and symptoms of IBC at www.eraseIBC.com . You need to see a doctor who is familiar with IBC and knows the proper treatment for IBC. I am a volunteer with the Inflammatory Breast Cancer Foundation since there are way too many medical professionals (as well as women) who are not familiar with IBC and disregard the signs and symptoms, which can end up proving fatal. Please see our website and watch one or two of the videos there and check it all out for yourself. The life you save may be your own.
Posts.Title: I am 20 found lump, nipple is inverting and need advice!

Posts.Content: Judy, My heart goes out to you.  I also have IBC and am 66 years old. I had chemo for 6 months (A/C then Taxotere), a right MRM, then almost 7 weeks of radiation.  Now I'm on Arimidex for 5 years.  My joints and bones are so stiff in the morning, but get better after I get going.  Luckily, I've got my husband in good health and he has been by my side through all of this.  He just retired last weekend and can now take me to all my appointments for follow-up testing without having to take time off work.   The other side effects I have from Arimidex are weight gain, sleeplessness and hot flashes every now and then.  The weight gain I hate, the aching joints and bones I can tolerate, the sleeplessness gets to me at times, and I'm just glad that I can nap whenever I want.   Many women I've talked to had horrible reactions during chemo...not me.  Others had problems during radiation...I just got burned badly in one area near the collarbone.  I feel I have been very lucky throughout all my treatments during this past year.  Now I am waiting to have tests to see how I'm doing after all this treatment. I'm hoping to be NED (no evidence of disease or no expiration date).  I try to stay positive and actually hand out a "Laugh of the Day Award" to someone who sent me the funniest email each day.  I let all my friends and family know I need to have something to laugh about each day. My online support group at www.ibcsupport.org is a group of women with IBC and some caregivers. They are very knowledgeable and glad to share that knowledge with all of us.  You can search the archives there on many topics and ask a question of the group any time. I would also be happy to answer any questions you may have, if I can. Hugs, Claudia in FL
Posts.Title: Third bout with breast cancer since 1995

Posts.Content: On 3/12/2009 kellyann wrote: Hi Everyone! I have just found out I have Inflammatory breast cancer. I am really scared because I have read that it is the worst of all breast cancers to get because it is so aggressive. I am to get a port put in my chest 3-24 so I can begin chemo. I see my cancer specialist on 3-23. So far I have only had the mammograms,sonograms, and biopsy done. the biopsy came back malignant and the doctor told me I have IBC. I knew it anyway from my symtoms, but it sure hit me like a ton of bricks anyway when the doctor told me and it made it "REAL" if you can imagine. Anyway, I am very worried how I'm going to do on chemo. I have chronic lyme disease already and have FMS also, I know, lucky me, haha! I would really welcome any advise you can offer me! Your friend, Kellyann Kellyann, I know exactly what you're going through since I was diagnosed with IBC in August 2007.  Luckily, I breezed through my chemo treatment, and I certainly hope you do the same.  I took a styrofoam cup full of ice chips with me to each treatment and sucked on those during the treatment.  I felt good enough after each treatment that my hubby and I went out to eat breakfast afterwards.  Not everyone feels that good, but I'm thankful that I did.  You can read the archives at ibcsupport.org to get an idea of what others with IBC went through at each stage of treatment.  There is a lot of info at that site and at eraseibc.com.  If you have any questions, I'd be happy to try and answer them if I can.  Claudia in Florida
Posts.Title: IBC: Found out I have it...need advise please!

Posts.Content: On 2/9/2009 Resourceful wrote: I had left bc & lumpectomy 2002 + radiation, now inverted nipple; my tissue is such that cancer does not show up on MRI, CT and mamograms.  My breast hurts and is lumpy.   I have had 5 cancers, one of which was lung cancer in 1998.   I  wanted to have a mastectomy on left breast and  dr refused to do it as he said radiated tissue does not heal and he personally did not want to take chance and I should wait to get  cancer. I cant take any more cancer or chemo, the chemo almost killed me, I stayed in bed 21 days with treatments, could not get out of bed so weak. Is there any treatment that would help oxygenate my tissue presurgery, i.e. hyperbaric treatment for a few months before surgery to help me, I simply have to have this elective mastectomy before it is too late.  I have never had metastasis..   I was stunned for him to say that.   What can I do to help myself rather than stay home and wait to die? I was cured of lung cancer.I feel well, really well.   I am 70.   When you said inverted nipple and cancer not showing up on tests, my mind jumped to IBC (inflammatory breast cancer), which is what I have.  IBC is highly aggressive and is treated differently than most breast cancers (chemo first to reduce the tumor size, then surgery followed by radiation and possibly more chemo).  Please check out the signs and symptoms of IBC, mention this to your doctor, and beg him to rule out IBC with a biopsy.  You may save your life.  There are also other causes for an inverted nipple, but please have your doctor rule out IBC first.  My doctor insisted that I be treated for mastitis with two 10-day treatments of antibiotics even though I was 65 years of age.  I kept insisting that I get a biopsy since I felt I wasn't a candidate for mastitis (usually found in young nursing women), and finally I got one.  The biopsy showed that I did have IBC and treatment was started within a week.  Many doctors do not know about IBC and have never seen a case of IBC because it is rare.  It is very commonly misdiagnosed as mastitis. A misdiagnosis can be a death sentence if the cancer spreads. It is either stage IIIB or IIIC when diagnosed.  If it's spread to other organs, it's stage IV.  I now try to educate people in the medical profession, not just doctors, about IBC.  I also try to educate the general population so they will know the signs and symptoms of IBC. You don't have to have a lump to have breast cancer, and there is a breast cancer that doesn't show up on a routine mammo.  I don't know of any doctor who tells you this.  All they say is feel for lumps and have your mammograms.  They should be saying to check for ANY changes in your breasts and notify your doctor of them.
Posts.Title: ?Would hyperbaria help riadiated tissue from bc so I can have a mastectomy.

Posts.Content: I hope Kailee will come back and let us know how she's doing and if she ever got a correct diagnosis.
Posts.Title: I am 20 found lump, nipple is inverting and need advice!

Posts.Content: Gayle, I'm praying that Kailee is having tests, which should include a "diagnostic mammo", not a routine mammo, which would be looking for the sheeting of the tumors and not a solid lump. IBC usually does not have a solid lump, although it can. She really needs to have her doctors "rule out IBC". I certainly hope she has checked out our website, www.eraseIBC.com " target="_blank" rel="nofollow">www.eraseIBC.com so that she is aware of the signs and symptoms. Sometimes you have to print stuff and take it to your doctor.  Claudia in Florida 4 yr survivor of IBC The Inflammatory Breast Cancer Foundation www.eraseIBC.com " target="_blank" rel="nofollow">www.eraseIBC.com
Posts.Title: I am 20 found lump, nipple is inverting and need advice!

Posts.Content: Please see a breast specialist, not your regular doctor. Inflammatory breast cancer is nothing to fool around with, as I know.  I was diagnosed with IBC in August, am now undergoing chemo.  Please watch the video at komotv.com/ibc and get yourself acquainted with many symptoms of IBC.  And then pass it on to someone else.
Posts.Title: Could this be cancer?

Posts.Content: I hope Kailee will come back and let us know how she's doing and if she ever got a correct diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Gayle, I'm praying that Kailee is having tests, which should include a "diagnostic mammo", not a routine mammo, which would be looking for the sheeting of the tumors and not a solid lump. IBC usually does not have a solid lump, although it can. She really needs to have her doctors "rule out IBC". I certainly hope she has checked out our website, www.eraseIBC.com " target="_blank" rel="nofollow">www.eraseIBC.com so that she is aware of the signs and symptoms. Sometimes you have to print stuff and take it to your doctor.  Claudia in Florida 4 yr survivor of IBC The Inflammatory Breast Cancer Foundation www.eraseIBC.com " target="_blank" rel="nofollow">www.eraseIBC.com
Posts.Title: I am 20 found lump, nipple is inverting and need advice!

Posts.Content: I've requested to add her as a friend, but have not received a reply. I can only hope she'll come back here and check in and let us know what's happening. I'm really worried because I know how aggressive Inflammatory Breast Cancer is, and you need to get a correct diagnosis asap. Been there, done that.  Claudia Inflammatory Breast Cancer Foundation www.eraseIBC.com www.komotv.com/ibc
Posts.Title: I am 20 found lump, nipple is inverting and need advice!

Posts.Content: I've requested to add her as a friend, but have not received a reply. I can only hope she'll come back here and check in and let us know what's happening. I'm really worried because I know how aggressive Inflammatory Breast Cancer is, and you need to get a correct diagnosis asap. Been there, done that.  Claudia Inflammatory Breast Cancer Foundation www.eraseIBC.com www.komotv.com/ibc
Posts.Title: I am 20 found lump, nipple is inverting and need advice!

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with IBC (inflammatory breast cancer) in August 2007.  I had about 6 months of chemo (adriamycin/cytoxin, then taxotere), had a right MRM in April 2008, then 6-1/2 weeks of radiation.  I started taking Arimidex in March 2008 (after I finished chemo), and I have had many side effects over the past 8 months: loose bowels (most annoying), stiff and sore joints, weight gain, sleeplessness, some nausea and vomiting...and maybe more that I can't even think of right now.  The side effects come and go, but as long as the Arimidex works I will continue to take it.   Claudia
Posts.Title: Arimidex Treatment

Posts.Content: On 2/8/2009 bonita36 wrote: hi,,i am new in this webpage...I'm 36yrs old with 2 kids,,about a moth a go my rigth nipple is been itching me very bad...I was escratching it when i was taking a shower and something yellowish came out of it..I got very scare...a lot of thigs are going to my head right now...  Although I don't want to unnecessarily scare you, I do think you should have your doctor rule out IBC.  Please check out the signs and symptoms of IBC (inflammatory breast cancer) as itching is one of them.  There are also other benign causes of itching, so you don't necessarily have to have cancer.  But you really should be checked out.
Posts.Title: worry

Posts.Content: Lucy, By all means, please seek a doctor's opinion whenever you see or feel ANY change in your breast, not just a lump.  The lymph nodes under your arm could be swollen, which can be another sign of cancer.  Don't ever feel like you're crying wolf when you're trying to save your own life or the life of someone else.  Let us know what the doctor has to say.
Posts.Title: symptoms

Posts.Content: I heard Dr. Ruddy speak last month on the Inflammatory Breast Cancer Foundation's radio podcast.  She is totally amazing and is trying to find funding for research into the causes of breast cancer. My hat is off to her.   Claudia in Florida IBC Survivor/Advocate
Posts.Title: Finding the Cause of Breast Cancer: Dr. Ruddy, a woman seeking to make a difference

Posts.Content: I'm another IBCer from the Class of 2007. I had 3 biopsies: a needle, a punch and a skin biopsy...and my IBC diagnosis was confirmed. I had chemo, right MRM, then 33 rads. Today I am NED and very thankful. So sorry you didn't get to NEDland.
Posts.Title: Inflammatory Breasts Cancer

Posts.Content: On 1/29/2009 dove111 wrote: I have had a lumpectomy followed by radiation for estrogen positive brest cancer - stage 1 - I am currently on Arimidex and have been for 3 years.  I have gained 45 pounds and am nauseous, have extreme hot flashes and some joint pain.  Anyone else feel like this and has anyone gone off this drug early. I've got IBC (Inflammatory Breast Cancer), stage 3B, and had a single mastectomy in April 08.  I've been on Arimidex since March 08, have gained way too much weight, am nauseous on and off, have plenty of joint pain and several other side effects that I can't even think of right now (good old chemo brain).  As long as it's keeping the cancer at bay, I will continue to take the Arimidex.  However, I could change my mind after 3 years of these side effects.  Since IBC is very aggressive and tends to recur, I feel it is important for me to take any steps I can to prevent this.
Posts.Title: Armimidex and side effects

Posts.Content: I have bone and joint  pain from the Arimidex.  At this point, I am just tolerating it and not doing anything for it.  I take so many pills each day and don't want to add even one more if I can help it.  At times, the pain is so bad that it wakes me up at night and I end up in tears.  I can understand why so many women actually get off Arimidex, but I'm really hoping to be able to continue with it (8 months so far) for at least 5 years.  Of course, the bone and joint pain is not the only side effect I have from Arimidex.  If it was, it would sure make it easier on me.
Posts.Title: Bone pain

Posts.Content: I've been on Arimidex since March 2008 and have many side effects, including bone pain.  As long as the Arimidex works, I will continue to take it and put up with these horrible side effects.  I take so many pills already that I just don't care to add more by asking for something for the pain.  Maybe you should ask your oncologist for something to help you bear the pain if it is bad for you.  There's no need to suffer the pain if you don't want to.
Posts.Title: right masectomy

Posts.Content: I posted about the same thing (Issels Medical Center) when I first joined a different online support group (for IBC - inflammatory breast cancer). The responses I got were that four former members had chosen to go to Issels and had later died. I chose NOT to go to Issels.   There are testimonials online at You Tube where people are saying they were cured there, but I heard that they were paid or given free treatment in exchange for their testimonial.  I have no idea who is right.  I just chose to not go to Issels, although they sure talk a good story when you contact them.
Posts.Title: Issels Medical Center
